posts.cooked:
Alright, so I’m trying to make my own simulation-style program that can somewhat accurately determine how fast a robot would move/slow down assuming it’s on a flat surface and the only forces applied to it are the motors and friction. I want this to be applicable to any motors inputted too. But for now, let’s make the NEO the example motor for this.

The NEO is rated to have a stall torque of 2.6NM and a max rpm of about 6000. How can I find out how much my robot would accelerate given the current rpm at which the motor is running? For  more context: The robot has 6 neos in it’s chassis, the robot weighs 56kg, and the chassis has a gear ratio of 10.75:1. Lets also assumme all 6 neos are running at the same speed and i have wheels with a diameter of 6 inches. I dont need super accurate results judt domrthing that will give a rough idea of how fast a robot would go and accelerate given the motord torque, rpm and robot weight

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
The Dillon Carey / Aren Hill design calculator has a Sprint Distance calculator which factors in things like Battery Voltage, Gear Ratio, Motor Selection, and Efficiency (averaging all the sources of friction and efficiency) to tell you the time it would take to drive a certain Sprint Distance.

I guessed on some other parameters, but your 10:1 gear ratio seems high, kinda slow. To sprint 20 feet it would take nearly 3 seconds and looking at the chart’s red Velocity line you can see that you would hit your top speed in the first 0.4 seconds of that. image 1812×757 124 KB

image 1812×757 124 KB

image 1812×757 124 KB

Remember to input wheel diameter, number of motors, and robot weight INCLUDING battery and bumpers.

link_counts.title: FRC Mechanical Design Calculator (By Dillon Carey and Aren Hill)

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
Ghozti:

The robot has 6 neos in it’s chassis

Reminder that 6 motors driving will be illegal next season.
any way to get a basic rundown on the math? i don’t plan to just use common frc motors nor apply this to just frc competitions. But in robots in general that use a tank drive style chassis

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
I don’t have time right now to do a writeup on this. I did some quick googling and don’t see a super great workshop on this topic from Spectrum or others, so I may make oneself cause it will also be useful for training our own students.

Another option instead of the previously linked sheet is the ILITE Drivetrain Simulator which also has a video tutorial/walkthrough. I haven’t used this simulator myself but it looks even more thorough than the the Dillon/Aren one and probably with the video maybe more useful to you.

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked: AMB Robotics Calculator has a drivetrain simulator similar to the links from Torrance, which has a docs page explaining how you could determine this info.
